statement.tex: \\ %text \textbf{Changing $\cot^{-1}\longrightarrow\tan^{-1}} Can the given integral \[ \qquad A = \int_0^1\cot^{-1}(1-x+x^2)\cdot dx \] be \underline\text{re-written} as follows? %

\\ %text \textbf{Further simplication} \underline\text{What is Z in the expression below}? \[ \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{1-x + x^2}\right) = \tan^{-1}x + \tan^{-1} Z \]
%
\\ %text Would the following be true given that \[ \quad A = \int_0^1\tan^{-1}x\cdot dx + \int_0^1\tan^{-1}(1-x)\cdot dx \] %
\\ %text What will \[ A = 2\int_0^1\tan^{-1} x\cdot dx \] evaluate to? %

reason.tex:
%text Generally speaking, dealing with $\tan\phi$ or $\tan^{-1} x$ is easier than dealing with $\cot\phi$ or $\cot^{-1}x$. Hence, we will \underline\text{try this approach}.
That said, % \begin{align} \cot^{-1} x = \phi \implies &\cot\phi = \frac{1}{\tan\phi} = x \\ \therefore \tan\phi = \frac{1}{x} \implies &\phi = \tan^{-1}\frac{1}{x}\\ \implies \phi = \cot^{-1}x &= \tan^{-1}\frac{1}{x} \\ \text{And so, }\cot^{-1}(1-x+x^2) &= \tan^{-1}\frac{1}{1-x+x^2} \end{align}
%text
Which is why \[ \int_0^1\cot^{-1}(1-x+x^2)dx = \int_0^1\tan^{-1}\left( \frac{1}{1-x+x^2} \right)dx \] %

\begin{align} A &= 2\int_0^1\tan^{-1}x\cdot dx \\ \text{Let }x &= \tan\phi \implies dx = \sec^2\phi\cdot d\phi \\ \therefore A &= 2\underbrace{\int_0^{\frac\pi{4}}\phi\cdot\sec^2\phi\cdot d\phi} _{\text{As x goes from }0\rightarrow 1,\phi\text{ goes from }0\rightarrow\frac\pi{4} } \\ &= 2\underbrace{\left[ \phi\tan\phi-\int\left[\frac{d\phi}{d\phi}\int\sec^2\phi\cdot d\phi\right]d\phi\right]_0^{\frac\pi{4}}}_ {\text{Integration by parts}} \\ &= 2\left[ \phi\tan\phi - \int\tan\phi\cdot d\phi \right]_0^{\frac\pi{4}} \\ &= 2\left[ \phi\tan\phi + \log\vert\cos\phi\vert \right]_0^{\frac\pi{4}} \\ &= 2\left[ \left( \frac\pi{4} + \log\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) - 0 \right] \\ &= 2\left( \underbrace{\frac\pi{4} -\frac{1}{2}\log 2}_{\log\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} = \log 2^{-\frac{1}{2}} = -\frac{1}{2}\log 2}\right) = \frac\pi{2} - \log 2 \end{align}
